Take a look at this network that performs logical XOR...

------------------------------------------------
    neuron id="0" type="bias"
    neuron id="1" type="in"
    neuron id="2" type="in"
    neuron id="3" type="out"

    connection src-id="0" tgt-id="3" weight="1.64327624043105"
    connection src-id="1" tgt-id="3" weight="-3.3017311279049"
    connection src-id="2" tgt-id="3" weight="-3.3025163810043"
    connection src-id="3" tgt-id="3" weight="-7.44947553716588"
------------------------------------------------

Activate Fn is (1.0D/(1.0D+(Math.Exp(-accumulator))))   - this has 
continuous output of 0.0 to 1.0

It surprised me because I was expecting at least 1 hidden node - the 
textbook example I have been using for tests has 2.

The truth table for the network looks like this:

0    1    2    3(t0)    3(t1)
--------------------------
1    0    0    0.83     0.01
1    0    1    0.16     0.05
1    1    0    0.16     0.05
1    1    1    0.007    0.007

Admitedly the seperation between true and false is small, but it's 
there. From this we can see that the non-linearity introduced by the 
feedback on the output node plays a crucial part. So although there are 
no hidden nodes, for practical purposes the output node is performing 
the role of a hidden node.

Just though i'd mention it as a nice small example of how an evolution 
based search has found an unexpected (to me anyway!) architecture.

Colin.
